abstract: <jats:p>Recent meta‐analyses of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropean ancestry subjects show strong evidence for association between smoking quantity and multiple genetic variants on chromosome 15q25. This meta‐analysis extends the examination of association between distinct genes in the <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>CHRNA</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>5‐<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>CHRNA</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>3‐<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>CHRNB</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>4</jats:italic> region and smoking quantity to <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sian and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>merican populations to confirm and refine specific reported associations. Association results for a dichotomized cigarettes smoked per day phenotype in 27 datasets (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropean ancestry (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content> = 14,786), <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sian (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content> = 6,889), and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>merican (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content> = 10,912) for a total of 32,587 smokers) were meta‐analyzed by population and results were compared across all three populations. We demonstrate association between smoking quantity and markers in the chromosome 15q25 region across all three populations, and narrow the region of association. Of the variants tested, only rs16969968 is associated with smoking (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>P</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> < 0.01) in each of these three populations (odds ratio [<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">OR</jats:styled-content>] = 1.33, 95% <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CI</jats:styled-content> = 1.25–1.42, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>P</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> = 1.1 × 10<jats:sup>−17</jats:sup> in meta‐analysis across all population samples). Additional variants displayed a consistent signal in both <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropean ancestry and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sian datasets, but not in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>mericans. The observed consistent association of rs16969968 with heavy smoking across multiple populations, combined with its known biological significance, suggests rs16969968 is most likely a functional variant that alters risk for heavy smoking. We interpret additional association results that differ across populations as providing evidence for additional functional variants, but we are unable to further localize the source of this association. Using the cross‐population study paradigm provides valuable insights to narrow regions of interest and inform future biological experiments. Genet. Epidemiol. 36:340–351, 2012. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.</jats:p>

title: Smoking and Genetic Risk Variation Across Populations of <scp>E</scp>uropean, <scp>A</scp>sian, and <scp>A</scp>frican <scp>A</scp>merican Ancestry—A Meta‐Analysis of Chromosome 15q25
